data.title: NZ Glen : BodyCombat fanatic
data.meta_description: Posts about BODYCOMBAT REVIEW written by nzglen
data.text:
I know Iâ€™ve been so slack with my posting. Itâ€™s this crazy time of year when everyoneâ€™s running around madly finishing up for the year â€“ myself included! Iâ€™ve been teaching 12-14 classes per week, and thatâ€™s on top of the 45 hours I spent per week at my day job, plus Xmas functions, BBQs, itâ€™s madness! I do apologise and rest assured Iâ€™ll kick the blog back into full swing come the new year â€“ Iâ€™ve got a lot of posts to write just need to make the time to do it!

Since almost everywhere in the world has launched BC46 Iâ€™m writing this more as a discussion piece as opposed to a review of what you can expect (since youâ€™ve all seen it pretty much!) and will make it short and sweet. Much like the last few releases this one has been getting a really mixed review â€“ Iâ€™ve read on various forums peopleâ€™s reactions and they vary from â€œdreadfulâ€ to â€œamazing!â€. My thoughts are that itâ€™s an â€œokayâ€ release. To be honest, thereâ€™s only one track I really dislike â€“ but, by the same token thereâ€™s actually not a track I really *love* either. For the most part in recent releases thereâ€™s always been one track that just stands out (BC45: Because the Night, BC44: Your Shining, BC43: Black Pearl etc) but in this release thereâ€™s not a track that blows me awayâ€¦ thereâ€™s no real â€œpeakâ€ per se. The release is also a wee bit unbalanced in that (with the exception of the warm up) the first half of the class the tracks are fairly short, and in the second half the tracks are long! Not too much of an issue but worth bearing in mind when you start mixing if youâ€™re an instructor. Brief review of each track follows:

1: Teenage Dirthouse (Topmodelz Radio Edit) â€“ Patrick McFly / Black Betty â€“ Masia

Well I hate to start a review on a low point, but I mentioned thereâ€™s one track in the release I really dislike and this is it. This warmup is a mess. Itâ€™s too long, itâ€™s unbalanced (over 6 minutes upper body and 3 minutes lower?) and the timing is all over the show. This is probably the worst warmup in the last 20 releases, even worse than Numa numa (which was silly but at least bearable). The lower body warmup music (Black Betty) is just horrid! Itâ€™s three minutes of screaming as far as Iâ€™m concerned. The upper body warmup is better, but still too long. It couldâ€™ve done without the third section of music (I do realise this wouldâ€™ve meant only one set of shuffle/jab/cross/jabs on the left but weâ€™d have survived) â€“ and the way the track speeds up is just awkward. I had members begging (not just asking but literally BEGGING) me not to do this track in only the second week after the release. Pardon my language but this track went down like a cup of cold sick. Thankfully the release only gets betterâ€¦

2: Shut Up & Kiss Me â€“ Spacegliderz

Yep good track 2. Not amazingly uplifting but light and fun and a pleasure to teach. I often change the lyrics and sing â€œshuddup and kick â€™em!â€ just to make it a little more combatty. The hook/upper/hook sequence is a tad awkward, to me it feels like it should be a jab/cross/jab but as we had that combo in the track 2 in the previous release I can see why they didnâ€™t use it. As with most of this release I donâ€™t love it but do like this track.

3: Truly, Madly, Deeply (S&B Remix) â€“ Cascada

Again, itâ€™s okay â€“ this track just doesnâ€™t go off. I guess â€œBecause the Nightâ€ set the bar pretty high. Not really sure why D&R pulled this one out of the archives, itâ€™s been in a few other LM programmes and is pretty old. Itâ€™s also fairly short and comparatively easy. Iâ€™ve not used this track since mixing and itâ€™s unlikely Iâ€™ll pull it out too often.

4: Kalinka (Russian Hit Mix) â€“ Captain Jack / Kalinka â€“ Za No Za

Wow, this oneâ€™s a little odd! Gets a few smiles due to its uniqueness! This track has grown on me â€“ when I first heard it I was â€œWTF!!â€ but now I donâ€™t mind it. Not that hard, and not that long! You can really have some fun with it â€“ reasonably solid track 4. Will probably use again in the future.

5: Contagious â€“ Boys Like Girls

Iâ€™m actually going to write a whole post about track 5s as I think maybe theyâ€™re a little lost as to what to do with them. They kinda seem all over the show. I was talking to a friend about this release at the GFX before Iâ€™d actually seen it and his comment was along the lines of â€œanother shitty track 5â€, which brings up a point â€“ if you look back at the last few â€œProud Mary, Ignorance, Without a Fight, Ballroom Blitzâ€¦â€ â€“ theyâ€™re not great (and thatâ€™s probably being quite generous). To be fair I way prefer this track over those by a long shot as the music is a little more uplifting â€“ but I do think something needs to be done to change the format. Perhaps they should be more of a power training track like 3 and 8 musically wise â€“ but involving a little more lower body (shuffling etc). I donâ€™t know â€“ all I do know is that the recent track 5s have been a lowpoint in the release for me â€“ and unfortunately having seen BODYCOMBAT 47 itâ€™s more of the same. Do you agree/disagree? Let me know below.

6: Spitfire â€“ GhostHunter

OUCH. Killer track. Evasive side kicks, esquivas and lunges. My legs are throbbing just thinking about this track! Iâ€™m not a big fan of the music but the pain is so God damn intense that I completely forget about it! Tâ€™is good ğŸ™‚

7: Braveheart 2006 â€“ Frantic & Gammer

This track has had mixed reviews. I actually donâ€™t mind it â€“ itâ€™s a little repetitive and the timingâ€™s a bit tricky but I overall I quite like it â€“ but some of my super hardcore regulars really donâ€™t! Speaking to them they thought it was too fast and too long (perhaps thatâ€™s due to it being so repetitious as Excalibur is longer and they love that one). This track will have you breathing out of your butt though â€“ so many many knees!

8: I Surrender (Hixxy Hardcore Remix) â€“ Cadence

Yeah good as well. Again, much like track 6, and 7, this track is quite repetitious. Hooks, hooks and more hooks. Itâ€™s not quite as long as Your Shining technically (7:53 vs 8:05), BUT, the â€˜run around the roomâ€™ piece of music at the end of this track feels shorter so I think theyâ€™re about the same length. Again, this track doesnâ€™t quite peak like some of our other T8s. Havenâ€™t taught it since mixing it out after week 3 but itâ€™ll be back for sure (which is the mark of a good track if you ask me).

9: Take It Off â€“ Ke$ha

All abs and no alligator!! Yee haa! Not the hardest ab track in the world but all good.

10: Wait Till You See My Smile â€“ Alicia Keys

Nice finish to the workout. Gentle song and chorey matches well, brings the heartrate back down beautifully.

So, let me know your thoughts! I know no doubt some of you will love this release (Iâ€™ve seen your comments on facebook haha!) but all I can do is call it how I see it. Apart from the warmup; which I admit *really* dislike â€“ I usually learn the basics of a combat track in about an hour â€“ the lower body track took me half a day to learn alone just because I found it so hard to even listen to the music! â€“ but, apart from that it is an okay release. It just didnâ€™t â€œgo offâ€ and didnâ€™t have a massive peak like most releases do (and BC47 definitely has! Track 4 ROCKED so look forward to that!)

As always love to hear your thoughts.

Bit behind the 8 ball here as most countries have released this now but for traditionâ€™s sake Iâ€™ll write a fairly brief review below. Once again, as always, this is just my personal opinion, and of course you may completely disagree (do tell me if thatâ€™s the case!).

To be honest, after I did this release at the filming (around 4 or 5 months ago) I wasnâ€™t impressed and thought Iâ€™d be absolutely â€˜bollockingâ€™ it (which I absolutely hate doing)â€¦ however, my opinionâ€™s changed. Itâ€™s very decent (if you donâ€™t love it at first do give it time â€“ itâ€™s one of those â€œgrow on you releasesâ€). Hereâ€™s a short blow by blow review of each track:

1. No Easy Way Out (Radio Edit) â€“ DJ Fait / Are You Gonna Go My Way (Ti-Mo Remix Edit) â€“ Kato feat. Ian Dawn

Well Iâ€™d have to say musically this is probably my favourite warmup ever â€“ great touch having the theme song from Rocky IV as an upper body warm-up, and, great remix too. Lower body works as well, nice driving beat. My only negative comment is that the track itself is possibly too long. Iâ€™m sure the Programme Directors couldâ€™ve created the chorey such that is wasnâ€™t necessary to have that last third of the lower body track (side kick sets and side kicks part). I mean to we really have to have back kicks in the warmup? Surely the chorey couldâ€™ve incorporated side kicks instead and not have the last additional bit. Back kicks only feature again in track 6 which is so slow thereâ€™s plenty of time to cue them. But, thatâ€™s just a wee niggle â€“ otherwise great track with a couple of surprises. 8.5/10 (would be 9 if just a minute or 2 shorter in length)

2. Back To Innocence â€“ Stephanie Smith

Grown on me quite a lot this one. Wasnâ€™t a fan at all to begin, and although itâ€™s not a track that I feel will go down in time as a classic itâ€™s fairly catchy and a good length; weâ€™ve had some crazy long track 2s (I was made for Loving You/United Vibe) and crazy short (Love Drunk/Beat It). Was one of the first tracks to get mixed out â€“ but will bring it back at some stage (unlike say Energy from BC44 which is unlikely to ever see the light of day again unless specifically requested). 6/10

3. Because The Night (Breeze & Unknown Remix) â€“ Cascada

Despite being used in BC38 this song has gone down fabulously. Highlight of the release for me. Builds perfectly, pulls back just long enough in the shuffle/double jab portion before slamming into the peak at the end of each half. The jab/cross slip/slip combo is awesome â€“ albeit does take a few sets for the members to time correctly â€“ once they do itâ€™s all smiles. Love it â€“ absolutely love it. 9/10

4. Take A Look Around â€“ Badlands Inc

Much like track 2 this track has grown on me. Really important you stay low in the lunges to get a great workout or the heartrate will drop too much. In my classes because the evasive side kicks just come from no where Iâ€™ve found they really need to be precued early and clearly (step left kick right works). I did find this one of the tougher tracks to learn as the chorey is uneven â€“ but yes, members like it and will come back in future mixes. 6/10

5. Proud Mary â€“ Dr John Henry

Low point of the release unfortunately. Obviously this is just my opinion but the cheesy song, dreadful cover, and odd repetitive chorey make for a long, long, long 5 minutes. Gets a few smiles first couple of times you teach it as itâ€™s so silly and uncombat like, but once the novelty has worn off itâ€™s just a bore. I understand why this track was in BODYATTACK 70 â€“ being a celebration release and the track having a 70â€™s feel to it â€“ but why put it in combat in the same quarter?? I mean I can understand when current hits are in multiple programmes, as they are â€œcurrentâ€ â€“ but a track from 40 years ago? Itâ€™s like Lisa O put it in attack and D&R went â€“ â€œgood idea â€“ weâ€™ll do that too!â€. Anyway, clearly Iâ€™m not a fan; 2/10

6. Russian Roulette (Blunatix Meets B-tastic Remix Edit) â€“ Felix DJ

First time I did this track at the filming I LOVED it. It blew me away â€“ I thought the music was beautiful and Rach presented it so well. However â€“ after doing it a few times yes, whilst lovely itâ€™s just too darn slow. Loads and loads of blocks, and while if you concentrate on staying really low in your stance youâ€™ll get a decent leg burn itâ€™s too long a recovery heartrate wise. Even if you really power into every block and kick itâ€™s still a big drop for the heart. But, nice track â€“ you can pull back and say very little when teaching and almost just use your eyes to cue the movements which is always nice as a contrastâ€¦ but, yeah, too slow and a bit long for my liking. 6/10

7. Goinâ€™ Out Swinginâ€™ â€“ Turbo

Other low point of the release for me. Hideous cover of a non-hit by MÃ¶tley CrÃ¼e. I guess if youâ€™re a CrÃ¼e fan you may love it (I was in my teens â€“ not so much now) but itâ€™s not a great track. Kinda cringe worthy really. To be fair I wasnâ€™t a fan of Kickstart My Heart either (another CrÃ¼e cover in muay thai just 2 releases earlier), but the chorey in this one is better IMO. Sorry, not for me. 3/10

8. See The Light (Styles & Breeze Mix) â€“ Paradise

Great finish. Musically really good â€“ the power hook is an unusual addition and to be honest not sure if itâ€™ll stay around (might go the way of the â€œsweepâ€) â€“ however lovely end to the cardio part of the class. Well used track (attack and pump before) but still works here. The tracks 8s in the last few releases have just been simply AWESOME, Overload, Your Shiningâ€¦ superb. D&R if you do read this keep it up. Love it. 8.5/10

9. I Can Transform Ya â€“ Chris Brown featuring Lil Wayne & Swizz Beatz

Two words; Alligator pressup. Yep, I think we all know my opinion on this move. To be fair the adaptation of it in 45 is much better than the way we did it in 44 â€“ but, still would prefer something a little less â€œcleverâ€ (especially in a 57 minute release â€“ not too much time to cue it for newbies to be fair!) 4/10

10. Black Box â€“ Stan Walker

Cooldown is really just down to musical taste so completely personal. Not too much to say here â€“ a little too much kata in this track for me â€“ musically nice finish â€“ just would prefer the last minute or so that weâ€™re doing soft katas to be used for stretches personally. But yeah, nice finish 7/10

Overall as I mentioned this release grew on me over the 2 weeks I did it solidly (teaching it 4 or 5 times per week). Itâ€™s not the hardest release in the world, the muay thai (where according to my HRM my heartrate usually peaks at up to 180 beats per minute) isnâ€™t that tough and is pretty short â€“ and track 4 and 6 does see your heartrate drop so cardio wise this isnâ€™t a release that will have you absolutely gasping for air. My only other comment is that itâ€™s over 57 minutes long â€“ if youâ€™re not an instructor that usually follows the â€œpush play and goâ€ philosophy you will now! However, itâ€™s got a couple of outstanding tracks in it and, most importantly the Members have reacted to this release really positively and thatâ€™s all that matters!

Because I was overseas for the last filming at the GFX in just over a month I get to see both BODYCOMBAT 46 & BODYCOMBAT 47 at the same time! Iâ€™ll keep you posted on those for sure. Again sorry for the delay in writing this guys and as always love to hear your thoughts!

Okay, time for me to come clean here. This is probably the hardest review Iâ€™ve had to write, and Iâ€™ve now written full reviews on BODYCOMBAT releases all the way back to BC37. Truth is, Iâ€™ve put off writing this for a couple weeksâ€¦ and the reason for that quite simply is Iâ€™m not really sure some of you are going to like or agree with what I have to say. Which of course is perfectly fine â€“ if you disagree absolutely tell me! I just would prefer to write reviews that are completely glowing and are full of sunshine, flowers and skipping merrily in fresh meadows ğŸ™‚

The thing is, I know a lot of people appreciate the fact I tend to call a spade a spade, and whilst I was tempted to sugar coat this review a little, Iâ€™m just going to step out on a limb and call it as I see it. I know I could be in the minority here, and reading feedback on BODYCOMBAT 44 on the Les Mills forums I may well be. But, Iâ€™ve had a few messages on facebook from a few of you asking my opinion, and Iâ€™m sure no ones going to respect me for being nice just for the sake of it.

I mentioned in my filming post on BC44 that I hoped the release would grow on me. Some releases definitely do take time, I always think of BC39, I didnâ€™t think that much of it at the filming and now I absolutely love it (Come With Me, Hardcore Angel, Cry For You and I Wonâ€™t Be Crying are some of my most played tracks ever!) So, I really wanted to give 44 a chance. And I have, I released over three weeks ago, Iâ€™ve taught the release in full over a dozen times now at multiple gyms all over the city (in fact of the five Les Mills franchised gyms in town I was invited to release at four of them). So yes, Iâ€™ve definitely given this release plenty of time to grow on me.

So, has it grown on me? Well for me the easiest determinant as to whether I love a release is how quickly I mix it out. Here weâ€™re given the guidelines of 2-4 weeks after launch before we start mixing. BODYPUMP 74 for example, three weeks after release and Iâ€™ve still not mixed out a single track. In fact, in my last pump class I started by asking the class if they wanted to do it again or for me to pull out some older tracks and the answer was a resounding yes, they wanted to do the new release again. I was thrilled about that as I did too!

Looking back at my last review (43) I wrote â€œLet me put it this way â€“ tonight is the first night Iâ€™m going to start mixing and the only cardio tracks I plan to mix out are 5 and 7. Thatâ€™s saying A LOT! To my mind those are the weakest tracks of the release â€“ the rest are stunning!â€ â€“ yes I used the word â€œstunningâ€ to describe a combat release! That was BC43 however, and that is definitely not a word I would use to describe BC44.

So, enough dilly dallying about with a long winded intro; Whatâ€™s the deal with 44. Okay, truth is I found this release disappointing. Donâ€™t get me wrong, there are a couple of parts of it I love, but, look at what I wrote about BC43 above â€“ after 3 weeks I only planned to mix out two tracks. With BC44 after the two week mandatory period was up 4 tracks went immediately, and pretty soon after that 8 were gone (by request). In fact, for the first ever time in my almost 3 years of teaching combat I actually had a member come up to me in release week and ask how long we â€œhadâ€ to do the release for. To my mind that really just solidifies the fact that BC44 just doesnâ€™t have the â€œwow factorâ€ of previous releases. And please donâ€™t think my members are feeling that way because Iâ€™m not trying to sell the release. I give every class my absolute all, in fact my good friend Raina came down from Auckland two weeks ago and participated in one of my combat classes. Being a close friend (and also being someone who attends the filming classes in Auckland with me) she knows Iâ€™m not really sold on the release â€“ yet came up to me afterwards and said there is no possible way anyone couldâ€™ve known Iâ€™m not a fan â€“ I really do give it my all.

So, hereâ€™s my 2 cents on the release on a track by track basis:

Warmup: Brighter Day (Monday 2 Friday Remix) â€“ Yanou / Use Somebody â€“ Ultrabeat

Warmups are far more music driven for me than any of the other tracks (possibly with the exception of a cooldown) as the choreography is always very basic, and musically I like it. I admit I had my doubts about using a remix of Use Somebody so soon after we had it as a cooldown in BC40, but the versions are so different itâ€™s not a factor at all. I do have a couple of wee comments, but they are very minor. I do prefer warmups without combinations, for example Iâ€™d prefer solid upper cuts followed by solid hooks as opposed to combining the two. The reason for this is itâ€™s much simpler to give set up cues when youâ€™re only doing one movement. What I mean by that is if we are only doing uppers I can just say things like â€œtarget is under the chinâ€ â€œelbows inâ€ â€œdrop your shoulderâ€¦â€ etc and itâ€™s obvious what move I am talking about as weâ€™re only doing one. But, if we are doing a combination I have to specifically state â€œon your upper cut your target is under the chin yadaâ€ then cue the hook in the same way â€œon your hook target is the side of the jaw, rotate your hip, lift your heel etcâ€. Just means I have to specify specifically what move to which I am referring and makes cueing a touch more complicated than it needs to be on the warmup (hey, I did say it was a minor point!). Same goes for the lower body warmup â€“ the back knee front kick combo just makes cueing a little more difficult than when we have these moves individually. Just means we have to say more, and Iâ€™ve always been of the opinion â€˜less is moreâ€™ when youâ€™re teaching â€“ you need to leave time for what youâ€™ve said to land. But, Iâ€™m just being really picky. I do like the warmup so letâ€™s just leave it at that!

Track 2: Energy â€“ Shinedown

Okay, hand in the air Iâ€™ll admit I am not a fan of this track at all. Just feels like a mess. I donâ€™t particularly like the â€œdecoyâ€ â€“ even though itâ€™s (apparently) derived from Tae Kwon Do (I have a black belt in TKD and I donâ€™t ever recall this move being a staple in the martial art â€“ but it was a few years ago now). Someone mentioned in a comment on this very blog that when we change the tempo up on the decoys they become too fast to do correctly and they have a point, for a lot of people they kinda turn into switches before the jab. The front kick off the back leg is a nice touch though, and I hope they incorporate that more into future releases, but for me musically and chorey wise this track just doesnâ€™t work. Hopefully many of you disagree.

Track 3: The Time Of Our Lives â€“ Sy & Unknown featuring Lou Lou

Yep, I do like this one. Definitely not as climatic as some of the past power training tracks (it doesnâ€™t build and go off like Send Me an Angel, Poison or Sweetheart as an example) but it is a good track (perhaps those tracks set my expectations too high?). The track seems longer to me than it actually is â€“ perhaps due to the fact itâ€™s five rounds. But yeah, solid track 3 and one you can have a bit of fun with due to the â€œyou and I could flyâ€¦â€ lyrics.

Track 4: Paint It Black 2009 â€“ Masif DJâ€™s / GIA (Skitz Clubb Mixx) â€“ Despina Vandi

Definitely this is one of the tracks that has grown on me. My only minor gripe is that thereâ€™s so much going on in the track that when thereâ€™s new people in the class thereâ€™s a lot of stuff to cue, and it seems that just as they get the movement right and it changes; moves like the shoot, ginga, jump kick, do take a few goes to get the hang of, would be nice if we did them a little longer before swapping to another. The shoot after the knees feels far more natural than the other way around (as we did in BC43), and the â€˜double shootâ€™ is a bit of a killer on the ol legs. Quick question though, have many of you experienced any lower back discomfort from this track? Iâ€™ve had a couple of members mention that to me, and Iâ€™ve checked their technique and itâ€™s all good â€“ just wondering if itâ€™s a common occurrence. The shoot is a very crafty way to incorporate lunges into combat, and it feels far more â€˜combattyâ€™ doing them this way than the way we did them in say â€œDonâ€™t Ya Wanna Feelâ€. Solid track.

Track 5: Ignorance â€“ ToneTonic

LM cover of the Paramore track. Nope, not a fan here either. This track is just all over the show. Chorey feels uneven, and Iâ€™m just not a big fan of loads of running in combat (ironically I love the running in BODYATTACK, I just feel attack has a much more natural fit). But we better get used to it as thereâ€™s loads of running in the track 5 in BODYCOMBAT 45 as well. Track fives in recent releases are always the weak point of the class for me and again this is no exception (and again thatâ€™s the case in BC45 too sadly). Perhaps if I was a Twilight fan Iâ€™d feel differently? This track again just feels like a bit of a mess to me. Notice the sound effects are back though??

Track 6: Ã¬Nessun DormaÃ® â€“ Lacrima

Interesting one this one. I donâ€™t dislike it, and I donâ€™t love it. I think perhaps D&R are starting to maybe try to be a little too clever here. Track 6 in BC43 was a great track, almost every one just LOVED it immediately and raved and raved about it; maybe they felt they had to outdo themselves with something equally as clever? Hmmmâ€¦ Opera in combat, still not sure about it personally. However, the classes arenâ€™t about me and the peeps seem to love it! Though, in my last combat class I gave them the option of doing it again or doing another one and â€œpirate trackâ€ was the resounding response. Itâ€™s definitely a recovery track, youâ€™ll find your heartrate drops considerably. Also, is it just me or is there a lot of lateral shuffling in this release? (warmup, track 2, and track 6).

Track 7: Metal Kombat For The Mortal Man â€“ ColorBox

I feel like a bit of a broken record here but again this track hasnâ€™t blown me away. Again, I donâ€™t hate it, but I definitely donâ€™t love it and I do feel that something REALLY special couldâ€™ve been done with a Mortal Kombat theme and this missed the boat a little bit. I think the problem is that the track doesnâ€™t really â€œpeakâ€ like my favourite muay thai tracks (Hardcore Angel, So What!, Raverâ€™s Paradise, Let the Beat Control Your Body.. I could go on and on). Just falls a little flat for me. Itâ€™s just missing a part that you can really sink your teeth into a just â€œgo offâ€ to. Again like track 5 did you notice the added sound effects? We might be slowly going back to the days of Natha and Gabby (ding ding anyone! ;))

Track 8: Your Shining (Hixxy Remix) â€“ Styles & Breeze

Now weâ€™re talking! Peak of the class, absolutely 100%. I loved this track at the filming, and I still love it now. Itâ€™s loooong (longest track 8 ever in fact) but thatâ€™s all good as it rocks! Builds and builds and is a climatic end to the cardio part of the class. Not to mention the first few times you launch it â€“ the looks on peoples faces when they realise the track isnâ€™t overâ€¦ priceless! Love the track and love the chorey. Love it so much in fact that Iâ€™m willing to let the grammatical error in the track title slip by ğŸ˜‰ Seriously awesome, and really in my mind the one track that absolutely saves this release from being very average.

Track 9: Put Your Hands On Me â€“ Crookers feat Kardinal Offishall & Carla-Marie

I have a personal theory about the inclusion of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu in combat that stemmed from a little thing Dan said along the lines of â€œwe wanted to put it somewhere and this felt like the best placeâ€ â€“ it kinda seems to me that they are doing BJJ classes, and need to justify that by including it (somewhere) in combat. As itâ€™s a ground fighting style it really canâ€™t go anywhere but here. Does it work? No. To be blunt itâ€™s a fricken nightmare. My combat classes are pretty much packed and thereâ€™s just no room in the GF room for the â€œwalking komodo dragon with an alligator pushupâ€ â€“ never mind the fact that thereâ€™s also not much room to do it on the stage! Hereâ€™s the other thing, if you watch the DVD the intro for this track is 3 minutes long. The track itself is 3 minutes long â€“ so weâ€™re spending as much time introducing a move as we are doing it? (well, actually considerably more in reality considering the komodo dragon/alligator pushup is only done for 2 sets of 4!). Itâ€™s overly complicated, requires too much space, requires too much of an introduction, and to be honest isnâ€™t even that much of a workout. Iâ€™m sorry to be overly harsh here but I really think this track crashed and burnt. When I started mixing for the first time, and announced â€œno komodo dragon todayâ€ the class actually cheered! (Iâ€™m not kidding!) Unfortunately, we might have to get used to that move as I canâ€™t see it going anywhere anytime soonâ€¦

Track 10: Doesnâ€™t Mean Anything â€“ Alicia Keys

Not too much to say about a cooldown, but like the music, nice song to bring your heartrate down, not too much kata, good cooldownâ€¦ still using it now in fact.

So, Iâ€™d really like your feedback here. Iâ€™ve spoken to other instructors locally and they feel pretty much the same about this releaseâ€¦ but what do you think? Am I being a bit hard on it? I know thereâ€™s always going to be absolute combat lovers who love anything and everything thatâ€™s put out â€“ and yes, perhaps I am getting a bit cynical in my old age. In short I just feel this release whilst is okay, really only had one track that blew me away (t8). Reading my review of BC43 I used words to describe different tracks like â€œstunning!, EPIC!, Love it!, FANTASTIC!, and Awesome!â€ â€“ in my review of BC42 I used words like â€œGreat track, Love this one! etc.â€, BC41 â€œOfficially my new favourite track 2!, Awesome finishâ€¦â€ but in BC44 my adjectives are far more toned back because the release for me just doesnâ€™t â€œrockâ€ like any of the more recent ones. In fact looking back I canâ€™t think of any releases I prefer less until we get back to the early 30s. But, Iâ€™m only one person and this is only one opinion.

Had workshop on the weekend â€“ the official release of BODYCOMBAT 39 â€“ the quarterly was HUUUGE! Absolutely loved it. Iâ€™ve done BODYCOMBAT 39 a fair few times now and feel Iâ€™m in a position to give it a decent review â€“ so here goes.

But (again with the but) having done the release many more times now I do have to say I like it much more than my initial impression. Hereâ€™s a track by track play for ya:

Overall Iâ€™ll say this. BC39 is a good release.
